The goal is to differentiate where the packet comes from: patch port (from other bridge) or not.

VM1 and VM2  are in same network.

No, packets from access port (aka tagged ofport) will not match dl_vlan in flow tables. Such action is similar to physical switch. There is no vlan tag in the packet header at all during the flow processing. The switch use vlan to determain where to flood packets, to which ports. That's not correct. All traffic coming into OVS through a tagged port, will add the VLAN tag to the packet. We can use dl_vlan to filter those packets.

That's precisely why we can have what you are describing in the previous comment. We can have two ports in two different networks with the same MAC. The tagged port will add the VLAN tag to the frame along with the src and dst MACs. The VLAN+srcMAC will be different on both ports.

I expect devstack will raise an exception here even before looking at the job result. I am right? Let me look :-)
I would prefer trigger a behavior by getting some info or configuration from topology class, not recovering from a failure.

Even if this is more elegant and shorter, it is not equivalent of replaced lines. The difference is here you restart services on all hosts instead of stopped ones. The final result should be the same when stops is successful. But if any of the stop commands fails raising an exception, and it is not the last one, then you will never record the cleanup function to be executed and you will leave service half stopped and half started. This is clearly a bug. You could therefore move the addCleanup call before the for loop or call the start from the tearDown method. Even on such case if any of the services fails to start, the start method will fail to recover all the other instances of the service on remaining hosts. The addCleanup has been designed for resolving this type of situation by rolling back any operation in the reversed order they are registered. Therefore it is better to use it as it has been intended: register as many cleanups as you need, instead of putting all of them in one single cleanup (IE please revert this line).
I would prefer trigger a behavior by getting some info or configuration from topology class, not recovering from a failure.

specs/newton/approved/nova-policies.rst.message: I think you should move this as an introduction in the 'Problem Description' section.
IHMO, the aim of this part is to propose in a single paragraph the aim of this spec.
Jed, could you add the link to the source code https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/3316fa85668ee96f4db1bbff0752de25ce4744af/nova/scheduler/driver.py#L61

To migrate an instance, we have to invoke the 'select_destinations' method by passing, as parameter, the associated instance RequestSpec object.

..code:: python

    @abc.abstractmethod
    def select_destinations(self, context, spec_obj):
        """Must override select_destinations method.
        :return: A list of dicts with 'host', 'nodename' and 'limits' as keys
            that satisfies the request_spec and filter_properties.
        """
        return []
Before to call this method, we can now set an unique destination host by updating the RequestSpec object parameter named requested_destination (new in object version 1.6)
this is the vocabulary by nova.
Could you add a HTTP link: https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/cfd64c976b8aaacaf09fd2a6303877674fcfada0/nova/scheduler/host_manager.py#L182
It depends of the scheduler implementation. Sometime, we can several hosts.

So, if we invoke the ``select_destinations``
method from Watcher strategies, the nova scheduler will reserve resources on destination compute node for nothing, if this last is validated. And Watcher will receive quickly a NoValidHost exception from the Nova scheduler. In this case, the strategy will not be able to compute other possible migration.
defined by my algorithm will be conform with the instance placement policies set by the admin.
I would like to be sure that migration actions proposed by a strategy have been validated on Nova side, before applying them on the cluster.
Should remove this duplicate block of text
I prefer validity (more the notion of time)
This part should be in the "Problem description". No ?
so what will be default behavior if an action can not be successfully completed? We ignore it, we stop the action plan ?
the making of an action plan, and its immediate execution.

When the watcher-applier service is ready to execute an action plan, it will first check globally if each migration action are validated by the nova scheduler. If an action is no more valid, the action plan will be set to FAILED, and none action will be triggered.

please, add a return carriage. + 
Before Action execution, we should check again the validity of this one ...
You should add the resource manager name (nova, and maybe later cinder, neutron ...) so get_nova_policies or get_policies('nova')
I have to first look at more precisely how to structure the information. This is not addressed yet in this spec.
we should be able to call select_destinations in 'trial' mode, i.e without resources reservation.
I have to complete the spec for this point.

I think there is another case:

 - Do we want Watcher to select instances to be moved, and also a preferred set of hosts to move it to, and let Nova Scheduler pick a host from that group that meets any constraints?

Ed Leafe:
Your second point says that Watcher does not select the target host at all.
I was not enough clear, this is was the purpose of this sentence => "We can also propose destinations to nova but without knowing the constraints"

Joe Cropper:
I totally agree, This is exactly the point of this specification. I'm also worry when there is many constraints.


IMHO, the first approach can be to retrieve the constraints but it seems that we have to wait a long time before that nova provides to us the RESTFul API that we need. So, I'm looking to a new approach, we could defined our own scheduler driver in nova.

If you have 10 possible hosts and only 1 is acceptable, with the multiple host change for live migration (https://review.openstack.org/276840), you'd pass in 10, and let the scheduler pick from that. No errors.

Watcher knows the Data Center constraints: CPU load; network load, temperatures, etc., that determine if the VMs are optimally arranged. It then makes suggestions for moving VMs in response to the data it knows about.

The scheduler knows nothing of the things that Watcher knows about. All it knows is when it is asked to move a VM to a host, whether that host can accept that VM.

You're trying to make Watcher know everything by essentially duplicating the scheduler's logic in Watcher. That duplication, as well as trying to hook into undocumented interfaces is what I think is wrong.

I agree that your blueprint can be the first step for Watcher. I will highlight this solution in the spec.

No errors. => this is very depending of the strategy, the number of constraints and the cluster configuration.
Okay, this is my second point, but I will replace by your.

Your second point says that Watcher does not select the target host at all. I'm saying that Watcher *does* select the target host(s), and all that the scheduler does is verify that one of the targets is acceptable.

The problem I have with this approach is that we don't realize the host isn't valid until we *try* the migration and it throws a NVH exception.  If there are 10 hosts, but only 1 valid target... we could get 9 errors before we ever find the one valid option.

Don't we think there's a better option for this?  I'm especially worried about when you have a large number of hosts in a data center...

BUT, I suppose we could do this as a starting point, but we just need to tolerate the NVH exceptions when we're trying the migrations.

This is indeed an eventual goal, but the timeframe for getting this as a *public* RESTful API that Watcher could consume is at least a year away, and most likely longer. So all of the following parts of this spec are at best only possible in the distant future. They cannot be part of Watcher now.

We can bet that one day this will happen and to avoid that watcher stay stuck, we could create a plugin that can call the nova-scheduler via RPC.
We will also help the nova community to make it happen.

I would rather see Watcher designed to work well with Nova as it exists, and then, when it changes sufficiently to warrant investigating a new design, consider the actual new interface when it exists.

There was a previous effort to separate the scheduler a few years ago (Gantt). It too promised a separate scheduler service with a RESTful API. After a few years of not getting very far, it was dropped. If projects had designed themselves to work with Gantt, they would have wasted their time. I don't want to see Watcher make that mistake.

No, the scheduler doesn't start an instance. The select_destinations method simply selects a destination. The calling service, Nova conductor, then takes the returned (host, node) tuple and attempts to start the requested VM on that node.

Yes, you are right. I will fix that. 
I wanted mainly to explain that it can't happen separately.

The scheduler doesn't consume resources; it simply evaluates hosts based on its current view of the host's state.

The issue is that while Watcher is planning its moves, the cloud is still operating, and VMs can be created, moved, and destroyed between the original call to select_destinations, and the eventual call to migrate a VM. This is a classic race condition.

It "consumes" only in the local HostManager; it doesn't consume in the actual hosts. The only "consumption" in the scheduler is in the case where it has been asked to find more than one host (for booting multiple instances). That's why it does a _get_all_host_states at the top of the loop, which queries the Nova DB for the current host states. Inside of the loop, it "consumes" from its local copy so that the next pass through the loop doesn't try to allocate the same resources. It doesn't touch the host, or the host resource records in the Nova DB.

This is the reason why I wrote that the scheduler is *virtually* consuming the resources. 

The point here, is to say that, if the strategy is calling massively the select_destinations method before the Nova DB is called, nova will raise the NoValidHost exception. Even, if the host hasn't instances. 

If you want I can share with you the code snippet that highlight the problem.

If you take a look at this line:
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/scheduler/filter_scheduler.py#L136
and https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/scheduler/filter_scheduler.py#L98

It says that the scheduler "consume" the resource. 

Here an concrete example of the problem that I want to explain:

T= Time X 
Cluster state = cluster configuration.

T-0 => Cluster state:
Host_1 (available 1 vcpu)
Host_2 (available 4 vcpu)

T-1 => watcher strategy call select_destinations(request_spec=4vcpu) 
---> selected_host= HOST_2

T-1 => Cluster state:
Host_1 (available 1 vcpu)
Host_2 (available 0 vcpu)

T-2 => watcher strategy call select_destinations(request_spec=1vcpu) 
---> selected_host= HOST_1

T-2 => Cluster state:
Host_1 (available 0 vcpu)
Host_2 (available 0 vcpu)

T-3 => watcher strategy call select_destinations(request_spec=1vcpu) 
raise NoValidHost

If we use select_destinations method in the watcher strategies that doesn't mean necessarily that we want to do this action, we just want to check if it is possible.

This is highly dependent on the class of scheduler being used, and the overall activity of the rest of the cloud. Additionally, the presence and number of cells being used will greatly affect performance. Many large deployments shard their cloud using cells.
I agree, but we should start somewhere. I just want to show that the default scheduler performances doesn't allow us to use it in the watcher strategy.

You say "blind"; I say "decoupled". :)

The design should be independent services that respect service boundaries.
Do we want that "watcher" to stay blind ?
It's also much less likely to ever be possible to do that.

Several reasons:

1) having the scheduler expose its configured filtering strategy will probably never happen.

2) being able to read both the request spec, flavor table, and resource tables will require a major change to the Nova API, and that's one that I know many (including myself) would not be in favor of.

3) Race conditions. While Watcher is trying to mimic the scheduler, the cloud is changing, and now instead of just a single racy process (scheduler), you now have two racy processes.
Reiterating the point made above: this *will not* happen for at least a year, and most likely longer. It may never happen.
nit: not only the FilterScheduler driver, but rather all of them, including the ChanceScheduler...
yes, you are right. I will fix that.
TBC, it's not yet a Newton bp, even probably not an Ocata too...

Right, that's exactly why using select_destinations() is not good, because the nova community explains that it's not for a dryrun.

Instead, you should rather ask all the resources by the REST API and try to figure out a best placement so the nova scheduler would accept it IMHO.

Can you please clarify what you mean by 'figure out best placement so the scheduler would accept it'?

The problem is that there's no [good/maintainable] way that Watcher would know about all the filters (some of which could be out-of-tree) someone is using, so we'd be left with a virtually non-maintainable solution.

I understand Nova doesn't suggest using select_destinations() for a dry-run, but can I ask that we re-examine this?  We all realize it's inherently racey, but I think that's a concession we could make for the time being; the alternatives are much worse, IMO.

Thanks for your time.  :)

Thoughts?

[Filters out of tree]=> I agree, this is a limitation of this approach. Do you think this is something that happen often ? 

We could integrate watcher in an Openstack distribution with a list of known filters. We could also integrate the filters out-of-tree through plugins in the strategies. However, this solution is highly dependent on the techniques used by the strategies. 
I agree that dry-run can be a first approach but in a long term this is not sustainable, IMO.
That's about maybe having a discovery API... Mmmm, probably, but we should be discussing about that later.
this would also make sense for other resource schedulers such as Neutron, Cinder, ...

This even more confirmed by the Use Cases listed regarding Nova events for SystemUsageData:
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/SystemUsageData#User_stories
where it says:
"As a systems integrator or enterprise cloud administrator, I want to monitor usage data over time so that I can optimize the utilization of my resources."

There is one more problem as far as I know: some large VMs cannot be migrated because of their size (Nova can't migrate the largest instances). But Watcher might still want to move them. Is that covered by this blueprint or select-destinations-filter blueprint?
IMHO, this is a nova problem. However, we can maybe take into account this problem.

I think that the race condition is unavoidable. Of course, multiple checks could be done in every step (in strategy, applier, action), but in the end of the day Nova is the ultimate "source of truth" so maybe it's not worth doing it multiple times?

I don't know how costly it is to get updates on Nova policies each time, but it will likely decrease the Watcher performance. Is it very likely that after the first check (in strategy), the policy will change so the initial plan cannot be executed? For that to happen an administrator would have to sit and change these policies all the time. Is this the typical scenario?

I would rather optimize for typical scenario, do the policy check only once and simply accept the fail from Nova in these rare cases when the policy has changed.

I don't want to address here the problem of the performances. 

I want to focus on => How watcher strategies should

IMHO, we can have two type of affinity constraint. 

First, we only consider the model obtained as the end of the reconfiguration process. ( we can temporaly accept a violation)

Second, the constraint cannot be violated during the reconfiguration process and at the end.

What do you think ?

Jean-Emile might talk about discrete vs. continuous constraints ?

With a "discrete" anti-affinity, the constraint must only be satisfied by the end of the reconfiguration. That means it is ok to have both VMs co-located temporarily during the reconfiguration.

Using a "continuous" anti-affinity, this temporary violation is denied. 

See "Higher SLA Satisfaction in Datacenters
with Continuous VM Placement Constraints" at HotDep 2013 (https://goo.gl/gkv6Nz). The slides: https://goo.gl/3OogeD
To me a VM with an affinity rule can be migrated but still has to obey by the constraints. I am not sure what temporally accept a violation mean?
I am assuming this will be clarified once we talk to he nova team.

From the DB? I like the snapshot idea and I do not believe that existing policies/constraints associated with running VMs will change too much over time.

For Netronome NICs (disclaimer: ex-Netronome employee), we had multiple netdevs associated with the PF:
* phys port representor for each of the ports
* "PF uplink" also referred to as "PF netdev"

There's more information in this guide: 

https://netronome.freshdesk.com/support/solutions/articles/36000081172-agilio-open-vswitch-tc-user-guide#smartnic-netdev-interfaces

IIRC, the VF config is duplicated on _all_ netdevs in that directory, but the switchdev field is only set for phys port representors. This was to keep compatibility with libvirt (it chose the first netdev in that directory to run the "ip link set vf mac" commands on).

That said, the only reason you should call this function with pf_interface == True, switchdev == False is when you want the original SR-IOV VEB or VEPA mode. In that case, libvirt's codepath has recently changed and it's no longer just picking the first netdev. I'm in favor of (in slight order of preference):

* Just raising an Unsupported exception if that combination pops up
* Printing a big fat warning (I think there are enough duplication in the kernel netdev ops to make things "just work")
* Silently doing the same thing.

So I try this and ... when the bug occurs it fails and stop as we don't ignore the error.

The error is double:


TASK [Check for docker cli] ***********************************************************************************************************************************
ok: [controller-0]

TASK [Double check the mon systemd unit is not consistent with the current mon] *******************************************************************************
fatal: [controller-0]: FAILED! => {"changed": true, "cmd": "systemctl is-active ceph-mon-${HOSTNAME}", "delta": "0:00:00.013274", "end": "2020-09-24 21:59:04.823473", "msg": "non-zero return code", "rc": 3, "start": "2020-09-24 21:59:04.810199", "stderr": "", "stderr_lines": [], "stdout": "unknown", "stdout_lines": ["unknown"]}
        to retry, use: --limit @/home/stack/play.retry

PLAY RECAP ****************************************************************************************************************************************************
controller-0               : ok=2    changed=0    unreachable=0    failed=1   


first it returns 3 so it fails, but notice the "unknown" stdout_line, it means that systemctl wasn't able to match the unit-file.

So we have two fixes to add:

 - first: ignore_errors: true must be added 

 - second: there is a typo as it is, it should be "ceph-mon@${HOSTNAME}" : notice that "-" is now "@"

But as dimitri, maybe we could use a more robust solution like:

  "ceph-mon@*"

as systemctl support glob pattern.

Note that in my testing "unknow" or "activating" (which happen when the bug is around) both returns rc=3, so ignore_errors seems ok, as we cannot distinguish between true error (unknow) and expected error (activating).

Any reason for using rm instead of stop ?

Because the ceph containers are already started with --rm option so we just need to stop them.

I saw a bug when the systemd unit wasn't able to start because "container already exists". This is the reason I put rm -f but ... I see the unit already do that when it tries to start the container, so stop should be enough.

So, docker upgrade get a special treatment at step2 and is updated there.  Nevertheless, this step3 is dedicated to "yum upgrade" run.

In my testing this happened before yum upgrade.

I think it should go in another step: step4 is pacemaker restart and step5 is some stuff that should happen after cluster restart.

We also have a post_update_tasks that run after all controllers have run their update tasks, still in a serial manner.

So maybe step5 is where this should go ? so that we are certain it happen after yum upgrade ?

We should keep in mind these tasks are duplicated for ffu: is the same pattern for such scenario?
I'm not sure about the step, so I'm open to suggestions

I have a slight "downstream" look at this.  pike to queens is maybe still relevant upstream .... but what is more relevant is fast forward upgrade.  Should we have some ffwd action ?  Not sure actually as docker is installed from scratch in osp13 so always the latest will be there no legacy systemd to deal with.

This still return rc=3 if that fails making the whole stuff fails just right there.

you need a "ignore_errors: true" there (simple) or a specific fail_when (complicated)
fails here means the case for which this patch is used when is-status != "active"
any specific reason why using stdout instead of rc?

step 5 is when we do other final tasks that may requires pacemaker to be up and running on the node.

environments/deployed-server-environment.message: It's interesting how it affects upgrades, especially when operator has own networki ng scheme for roles

If the operator has own network config they would anyway override these in their environments/templates.

We're planning to have a top level parameter/toggle (not role specific) 'NetworkingWithAnsible: true'  which can be switched to false if required with upgrades.
Thanks Rabi for explanation. I would say it would be nice to update documentation explaining how to transform templates to ansible based.
With deployed server environment being the default, does this make all deployments use net_config_static_bridge.j2 now?

The doc's [1] and [2] refer to including the default in-tree environment. The default in that file is ../net-config-static-bridge.yaml, but typically a environment to override the 'OS::TripleO::{{role.name}}::Net::SoftwareConfig:' would be included after that. It could be using one of the env's we ship, but most likely it's a deployment specific environment file pointing at deployment specific nic-config templates.

Since this set ansible to 'true' the users intended resource registry overrides for nic-templates will not have any effect.

Should we add a validation to stop if the resource_registry entries are not 'OS::Heat::None'? To give the user a hint to either migrate to ansible tempaltes or set '{{role.name}}NetworkConfigWithAnsible: false' in their environment to continue using the heat templates?


I think this is'nt just something we want to disable for upgrades, we don't want to break people who re-use a procedure for deploying multiple clouds?


[1] https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/provisioning/baremetal_provision.html#deploying-the-overcloud
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/features/deployed_server.html#deployment-command

If they use this or any in-tree environments it would switch. As mentioned earlier we would make this flag global and they can set it to false (with upgrades), if they override with some custom nic config.

I can't see a better way to let people to migrate to the new thing.

One of the key cases where we will need to use this new "subcloud reinstall" CLI is when we have a failure while upgrading a subcloud and the upgrade fails in a way where the only recovery possible is to re-install the subcloud. Based on this point, it sounds like that won't be possible, because the software_version of the subcloud would still be set to the old release. What additional work would be required to make that work? Could we just change this case to update the subclouds software_version to the new version automatically? I assume we can't re-install the subcloud with the old software version once the System Controller has been upgraded (which is the case here).
Thanks Yuxing. That sounds good to me. We'll want to update the end user documentation for upgrades to explain how that will work.

Based on the previous discussion with John, We can upload the image into dc-vault. After that, an additional job will be expected, using "dcmanager subcloud update" to update the software version and delete the existing image path. Then we can re-install the subcloud using the existing configuration. We believe this will offer more flexibility to the users.
